MARTHA DANA RUST is Associate Professor of English at NYU. She is the author of Imaginary Worlds in Medieval Books: Exploring the Manuscript Matrix and, most recently, “The Architecture of the Infinite Library: Teaching Intertextuality and Bibliography with The Name of the Rose,” in Postscript to the Middle Ages: Teaching Medieval Studies Through Umberto Eco’s The Name of the Rose. She is currently at work on a book project, “Item: Lists and the Poetics of Reckoning in Late-Medieval England,” which examines, among other things, the medieval arts of memory.  Spring 2014 Great Inventions in World History: Breakthrough Technologies that Changed the Course of Civilizations FRSEM-UA 508; class # 14598 Instructor: Richard W. Hull  syllabus Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) This seminar is an exploration in human ingenuity, from antiquity to the twentieth century. It focuses on eighteen key inventions that profoundly affected the course of civilizations and that changed the way people lived and thought about themselves and the world around them. It examines the origins of the inventions, the individuals or groups that developed or conceived them, their initial impact on the societies of their inventors, their diffusion to other cultures and ultimately their impact on a global scale. It considers the transfer of technical knowledge from one country or culture to another and how it is modified and adapted by the recipients and may trigger a different but improved or related invention. In the process, we examine the interaction of technologies and society. Some inventions constitute “bricolage,” taking available resources and cobbling them together to create entirely new uses. Each invention we study generated a veritable revolution in the way humans interacted with each other, organized their lives, and mobilized their human and natural resources. In some cases we consider how specific inventions improved the human condition and/or degraded it. We explore the very idea of “invention”and weigh situations or intellectual challenges that gave rise to inventive impulses. We pose numerous questions: Why do some societies enthusiastically embrace a given invention or innovation while others reject it as see it as a threat? How do some groups attempt to monopolize an invention and endeavor to prevent its spread to other governments or cultures? The scope of the course is expansive, running from such geniuses as al-Khwarizmi and his algorithms in the ninth century C.E. to Steve Jobs and the computer in the twentieth. RICHARD HULL is Professor of History. A specialist in African and European history, he is the author of numerous books, including African Cities and Towns, Modern Africa , and Munyakare: African Civilizations , as well as coauthor of the two-volume World Civilizations . He has received both the Great Teacher Award and three Golden Dozen Awards for Teaching Excellence.  Spring 2014 Tolstoy’s War and Peace FRSEM-UA 509; class # 14599 Instructor: Anne Lounsbery  syllabus Tuesday, 11:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) Our first priority is a careful reading of Tolstoy’s massive novel (if it is in fact a “novel”: this is one of the questions we address), with the goal of understanding how the text works. We also consider the book’s historical context, the sources that Tolstoy drew on, its place in his oeuvre and thought, its place in the Russian tradition and in “world” literature, and the various uses that have been made of it since its initial publication. ANNE LOUNSBERY is Associate Professor of Russian Literature and chair of the Department of Russian & Slavic Studies. Her Ph.D. is in Comparative Literature, and she writes chiefly about nineteenth-century Russian, European and American prose. Her first book Thin Culture, High Art was on Russian and American literature; she is currently finishing a book on Russian novels and geographic space, Life Is Elsewhere: Symbolic Geography in the Russian Novel . Tolstoy's War and Peace is Professor Lounsbery's favorite book, and she never gets tired of re-reading it (most recently last summer, in Russian, on her iPhone). She has won the Golden Dozen Award for Teaching Excellence and enjoys working closely with undergraduates. Philosophizing with Shakespeare FRSEM-UA 510; class # 16302 Instructor: Tom Gerety  syllabus Tuesday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Thursday 3:30–4:30 p.m. One of the fascinating things about William Shakespeare is that we can never be sure if the exchanges and speeches he gives to his characters show his own convictions or, more likely, his conception of how kings and queens and lovers would think and feel. This seminar examines several of his greatest plays, including King Lear, Hamlet, The Tempest , and The Merchant of Venice . We study these and a few other plays in depth and with special attention to the ideas and arguments in them about life and death, the relations between the sexes, and between the classes. We consider the views his characters articulate about love and hatred, God and morality, virtue and vice. We try to understand what he thought about government and coercion, and about the limits of freedom and the inevitability of oppression and tragedy. We read (and see, on stage and on film) his plays and look to his great sources such as the King James Bible and the Essays of Michel de Montaigne. We learn all that we can about his life in Stratford and London, the world of the stage and court, and the great political and religious controversies of his time in England and Europe. We find that Shakespeare was in many ways not just an artist but a philosopher. His gift for summarizing and personifying ideas make him an elusive but important figure in the history of ideas. He stands on the bridge, as it were, between the Renaissance and the modern world. His ideas–or those to which he gave such powerful voice–propelled England and Europe towards the modern world of science, skepticism and materialism that we now inhabit. TOM GERETY, Collegiate Professor, joined the NYU faculty in 2005, having first come to NYU two years earlier to head the Brennan Center for Justice at the Law School. Before then he served as President of Amherst College from 1994 to 2003 and of Trinity College in Hartford, Connecticut, from 1989 to 1994. From 1986 to 1989 he was the Dean and Nippert Professor at the College of Law of the University of Cincinnati. As a law professor he taught and wrote on constitutional law and political philosophy, with a special emphasis on First Amendment freedoms, including speech, privacy, and religious freedom. With Judy Woodruff, he wrote and narrated a PBS series, Visions of the Constitution , funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities. He is the author, most recently, of The Freshman Who Hated Socrates . The Remarkable Normans: Europe from 911 to 1204 FRSEM-UA 511; class # 16303 Instructor: Jill N. Claster  syllabus  Thursday, 2:00–4:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 2:00–3:00 p.m. Few people in all of European history can boast a history of achievements comparable to that of the Normans in the nearly three hundred years following the founding of the duchy of Normandy in 911. From the tenth century until 1204, there was not a single important event in which the Normans were not involved or did not play a pivotal role. This course follows the Norman expansion: the conquest of England, of Sicily and southern Italy, of large parts of France, and cities in the eastern Mediterranean. The Normans were initiators and leaders of the crusades to the Holy Land and they fought as well in Spain against the Muslims. Although these descendants of Viking invaders never lost their taste for adventure and their warlike spirit, the Normans were also great organizers and the government in Normandy, as well as in the places they conquered, were the most advanced and efficient in all of Europe. They left a rich legacy in every field imaginable: art and architecture, religious institutions, political organization, and educational institutions. The Normans stood at the forefront of a long period of material, cultural and spiritual progress in Europe, and this seminar studies the many gifts the Normans gave to European civilization. JILL N. CLASTER is Professor of History Emerita with a specialty in the Middle Ages; she has taught and studied the era of the Crusades extensively and is the author of the recently published book, Sacred Violence: The European Crusades to the Middle East, 1096–1396 . She served as Dean of the College of Arts and Science and as Director of the Kevorkian Center for Near Eastern Studies. She was the recipient of a Fulbright grant and was honored with the Distinguished Alumni Award by the Alumni Association of NYU.  Spring 2014 Nuclear Energy FRSEM-UA 512; class # 14600 Instructor: Antoine Cerfon  syllabus  Monday and Wednesday, 3:30-4:45 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) Nuclear power currently provides 13% of the world's electricity and is expected to play an important role in the diversified energy mix that countries are developing to meet the world's growing energy needs. As a carbon-free, continuous energy source, it is an attractive solution for base-load electricity production, and a desirable complement to intermittent sources such as solar and wind. However, it also faces serious technological, economical and societal challenges that question its development. In this seminar, we follow a multidisciplinary approach to explore the different dimensions of the debate about nuclear power. We look at the basic nuclear physics in the core of power plants, the different power plant concepts and their engineering solutions, the nuclear fuel cycle, the issues of waste, safety and proliferation, nuclear power economics, and the place of nuclear energy in the global energy landscape. ANTOINE CERFON is Assistant Professor of Mathematics at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences. He obtained his Ph.D. in the Nuclear Science and Engineering department at MIT, and stayed there for two more years as a post-doctoral researcher before joining NYU in 2012. His main area of study is in plasma physics for particle accelerators and nuclear fusion applications. Introduction to Aesthetics FRSEM-UA 513; class # 16306 Instructor: Eduardo Subirats  syllabus  Monday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday 3:30–4:30 p.m. This seminar focuses on four major Western theorists of aesthetics: Schiller, Hegel, Schopenhauer, and Nietzsche. It will reconstruct central categories such as form, beauty, genius, and myth. It also will analyze four programmatic works of art: modern “cubism” (Picasso), a Greek tragedy (Aeschylus’ Prometheus Bound ), a German trickster ( Till Eugenspiegel ), and a French revolutionary painter (Courbet’s Atelier ). Its ultimate goal is a critique of contemporary artistic decadence and anti-aesthetics. EUDARDO SUBIRATS is Professor of Spanish and Portuguese. His research interests include Spanish intellectual history; the Counter-Reformation and the colonization of Spanish America; the Enlightenment; avant-garde theory, artistic movements in Spain and Latin America; and the modern Latin American and Spanish essay. Among his many publications are Linterna Mágica; El continente vacío; Da vanguarda ao pós-moderno; Memoria y exilio; Viaje al fin del Paraíso. Un ensayo sobre América latina; and Filosofía y tiempo final.  Spring 2014 Xenophon of Athens—Cavalry Commander and Socratic Philosopher FRSEM-UA 514; class # 14601 Instructor: Vincent Renzi  syllabus  Tuesday, 12:30-3:15 p.m. Required Cohort meeting: Monday, 2:00–3:00 p.m. The greatest ancient you’ve never heard of, Xenophon of Athens (c. 425–355 B.C.E.) was a brilliant general, student of Socrates, and renowned author. His heroism leading the army of the Ten Thousand inspired the conquests of Alexander the Great and Julius Caesar. His political philosophy informed the thought of Cicero, Machiavelli, Franklin, and Jefferson. When knowledge of Greek was still required for admission to college, his fame was ubiquitous, as his writings formed the basis of the pre-college curriculum. Readings, in English translation: Apology of Socrates, Symposium, Oeconomicus, Memorabilia, Cyropaedia, Cavalry Commander, Anabasis , and the film based on the latter, The Warriors (1979). VINCENT RENZI is Clinical Associate Professor in the Foundations of Contemporary Culture and of Classics. He serves as a director of undergraduate studies for the College Core Curriculum, NYU’s general education curriculum. A scholar of ancient Greek philosophy, he also has interests in arts and aesthetics and in 19th and 20th century philosophy, and is a recipient of the College's Golden Dozen Award for Teaching Excellence. Perception of Art FRSEM-UA 515; class # 16494 Instructor: Denis Pelli  syllabus  Thursday, 2:00–4:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday, 3:30–4:30 p.m. We apply the scientific methods of perception research, psychophysics, to explore and understand how people experience art. A few artists (e.g. a painter and a photographer) visit class or invite us to their studios to talk about the creative process and answer questions. We visit current shows in museums and galleries that address questions that arise in class--for example, do artists distinguish painting for themselves from painting for the public? Why is a figure like Philip Guston so popular among fellow painters, but unpopular with the public and critics? Pairs of students collaborate on an experiment answering some question or topic bearing on the perception of art, which is written up as a term project. DENIS PELLI, Professor of Psychology and Neural Science at NYU, has contributed new measurement techniques, major empirical findings, and useful theoretical accounts of object recognition. As a psychophysicist, he invented many widely used and highly cited methods for testing how vision works. His 150 papers on object recognition have been cited nearly 10,000 times. His scientific expertise is complemented by an informal knowledge of art. He grew up in a family of architects and a landscape designer (Pelli and Balmori) that spends most of its time together talking about how things look and why. He enjoys sketching and also helped a choreographer produce a ballet designed to be seen in peripheral vision. For more on his work, visit http://denispelli.com.  Spring 2014 Architecture in the City FRSEM-UA 516; class # 14602 Instructor: Marvin Trachtenberg  syllabus  Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 10:00–11:00 a.m. Note: conflicts with Principles of Biology I (Monday and Wednesday 9:30–10:45 a.m.) This seminar introduces students to key themes in western architecture from prehistory to postmodernity. It bridges immediacy and history using the buildings and spaces of our city as a primary object of study. Key texts are discussed, but emphasis is placed on the experience and understanding of buildings and their sites through media (photography and film) and direct encounters with the built environment of New York City. Themes such as the ecological basis of architecture, the question of nature, culture, and landscape, and architecture as idea, process, artifact and space are explored along with other topics relevant to the understanding of architecture. As an undergraduate, MARVIN TRACHTENBERG studied English literature at Yale with Harold Bloom. At the the Institute of Fine Arts, he turned to premodern architecture under Wolfgang Lotz, Richard Pommer, and especially Richard Krautheimer, who supervised his monograph on the Florentine Campanile (awarded the Society of Architectural Historians’ Hitchcock Prize). After a return to modernity with his Statue of Liberty and a decade producing a survey of architectural history ( Architecture from Prehistory to Postmodernity ), Trachtenberg again focused on pre-modern Italy with his radically revisionist (and award-winning) study of trecento urbanism, Dominion of the Eye . Issues raised by structures with long building histories and multiple architects led him to formulate the ideas discussed in Building-in-Time from Giotto to Alberti and Modern Oblivion (George Sarton Prize in History of Science, Ghent University). He is currently completing a book, on new discursive terms, for Yale University Press on Brunelleschi and the Pazzi Chapel. Since 1967 he has taught at the Institute of Fine Arts, where he is Edith Kitzmiller Professor of Art History. Spain in 1492: From the 'Moor's Last Sigh' to the Conquest of the New World FRSEM-UA 517; class # 16558 Instructor: Sarah Pearce  syllabus  Monday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday 3:30–4:30 p.m. The year 1492 in Spain is the very definition of a watershed. Four major, related events took place that completely altered the social, political, religious, intellectual, literary and linguistic landscape: the city of Granada, the last Muslim principality in Spain, fell to the Catholic crown of Castile and Leon; the order was signed and carried out expelling or forcing the conversion of Spain’s Jews; with Spanish backing, Christopher Columbus made his first voyage to the New World; and the first grammar of a vernacular Romance language, Castilian, appeared in print and was dedicated to the queen in honor of her imperial ambitions. This course examines literary and historical writing about these events. Through careful reading of primary sources and attention to modern historians’ rhetoric in writing about 1492, students explore how these events were implicated in the formation of national and religious identities in late medieval and early modern Spain. Reading in a wide variety of genres leads to diverse writing assignments in a variety of genres to help prepare students for further coursework in the liberal arts. S.J. PEARCE is an assistant professor in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. She returns to NYU after having held the Apfelbaum Fellowship in Judaic Studies at the University of Pennsylvania during 2012-13, where she completed a book-length manuscript entitled "No Achievement But Through Arabic" in which she explores the attitudes of medieval Spanish Jews towards reading and writing in the Arabic language. She tweets about the Middle Ages @homophonous. Urban Objects: How Things in the City Make Life Possible or (Almost) Impossible FRSEM-UA 518; class # 16559 Instructor: Harvey Molotch  syllabus Wednesday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 11:00 a.m.–noon We concentrate on very ordinary things: trash bins, stop signs, lamp posts, turnstiles, fences, and whatever else we encounter in the course of public city life. We trace out where these things come from, what caused them to take their specific forms and the way they cost or benefit social groups in particular ways (e.g. women versus men, kids versus adults, rich versus poor). Our interest is in public space, public life, and private benefits as revealed by the things we see, touch, jump over, ignore, vandalize and use. All along, we read about urban space, the use and abuse of the city, and the role of physical objects in our lives. We do first-hand studies of people’s encounters with these artifacts in real time. Each student chooses one or more objects for preliminary write-up(s) and then hones in on one for a final term paper. HARVEY MOLOTCH, Professor of Sociology and Metropolitan Studies, has authored many articles and books, the most recent being Against Security: How We Go Wrong at Airports, Subways, and Other Sites of Ambiguous Danger . A prior book, Where Stuff Comes From, analyzes the world of product development and design. His awards include: Distinguished Contribution to the Discipline of Sociology, Award for Lifetime Achievement in Urban and Community Studies, and Lifetime Achievement in Sociology of the Environment and Technology.  Encountering Martin Luther King, Jr. FRSEM-UA 519; class # 16575 Instructor: Philip Kunhardt  syllabus  Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with Physics I (Tuesday and Thursday 12:30–1:45 p.m.)  Few historical figures are more revered or transcendent than Martin Luther King Jr. But as David Levering Lewis wrote thirty-five years ago, America’s canonization of him has draped him in such a cloak of mythology that “in a sense we have sought to remember him by forgetting him.” This course seeks to vividly remember the human being at the center of the most significant popular movement in U.S. history, one that took up the unfinished legacy of the Civil War and Reconstruction eighty years after the nation turned its back on social and racial justice. Students explore King’s thought, oratory, character, and public actions in a way that will make him unforgettable to them. We consider his tenaciously held philosophy of nonviolent social change, and his growth from a southern Baptist minister to a leading civil rights activist to a visionary leader of global human rights and peace. We ask if he was a radical or a moderate and why he felt history had “hunted him down,” as he once claimed to fellow activist Rosa Parks. In what ways can new information about his inner conflicts and personal flaws change our appreciation of his moral stature? And how do we understand him in the context of his times, amidst fellow activists, adversaries, elected leaders, and critics during one of the most volatile, freedom-advancing periods of American history? Using film and little-known radio interviews as part of the class research, as well a challenging immersion in some of the most significant King literature, the course, coming in the fiftieth anniversary year of the March on Washington, makes King and his times newly relevant to our own vastly changed but still violence-prone and violence-haunted world. PHILIP KUNHARDT is Distinguished Scholar in Residence in the Humanities, and teaches history and biography in the College of Arts and Science. He focuses on the lives of transformative figures and has co-authored five books, including Looking for Lincoln, The American President , and P.T. Barnum: America’s Greatest Showman . He was also writer and co-producer of more than a dozen documentary films for PBS, ABC, HBO, Discovery, and others, including the ten-part PBS series The American President , and the sixteen part Freedom: A History of US. Before coming to NYU he was a Bard Center Fellow at Bard College in Annandale, New York. Writing the Self and New York FRSEM-UA 520; class # 18468 Instructor: David J. Dent Tuesday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Thursday 3:30–4:30 p.m. In this course students begin the semester by dusting off their college admissions essays. The first assignment requires students to explore the ideas of the personal essay beyond the individual and develop the essay into a piece of narrative nonfiction. Beyond that first assignment, students spend the semester exploring the city of New York through a series of writing assignments on urban life. Students also read several classic pieces of literary journalism, personal essays and fiction about life in New York City. DAVID J. DENT is Associate Professor at New York University where he holds a joint appointment at the Arthur Carter Journalism Institute and in the Department of Social and Cultural Analysis. He created the course “Deconstructing Obama” and teaches courses in journalism and non-fiction writing. He is the author of In Search of Black America , which was a New York Times Notable Book, and founder and editor of an election blog: bushobamaamerica.com. He has written for the New York Times, Playboy, GQ, Salon, the Washington Post , and many other publications. He is author of the forthcoming The American Extreme , to be published by St. Martin’s Press, and The Best Essay of Your Life: The College Admissions Essay , to be published by Random House. He and his wife Valerie are co-founders and directors of www.writeforthefuture.com . The organization uses the tools of journalism to help middle and high school students become better writers, a method detailed in The Best Essay of Your Life.   Spring 2014 Visuality and Literature FRSEM-UA 521; class # 14603 Instructor: Jennifer Cayer  syllabus  Tuesday and Thursday, 11:00 a.m.-12:15 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) In this course we examine twentieth-century and contemporary essays, novels, short stories and plays that are preoccupied with the visual, perform visually, or integrate images within narrative. Some of these works respond directly to pieces of visual art or analyze forms of seeing; others include images such as photographs or drawings. This is a writing-intensive course. While actively discussing the course materials, students consistently and frequently engage them through critical and creative, formal and informal writing. One of our goals is to deepen our own practices of seeing and using visual evidence as a method toward writing personal, exploratory, and persuasive essays. Topics may include: memoir, documentary works, photography, film adaptations, comics, graphic novels, artists books and surrealism. JENNIFER CAYER is a Senior Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program at NYU. She taught dramatic literature, performance studies, and cultural theory in the English Department at Amherst College where she was awarded a Copeland Fellowship on the Future of the Humanities. She has also taught at The University of Massachusetts-Amherst and served as a Five College Women’s Studies Research Center Associate. Her work has appeared in a number of journals, including Theater Journal, Brújula, E-Misférica, The Hunter On-Line Theater Review, and TDR: The Drama Review . She is a past recipient of NYU’s Outstanding Graduate Student Teaching Award, where she received her Ph.D. in Comparative Literature.  Spring 2014 Into the Urban Wild: Nature Writing and the City FRSEM-UA 522; class # 14604 Instructor: Tara K. Parmiter Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) Essayist Loren Eiseley asserts that “even in New York City there are patches of wilderness,” encouraging his readers to rethink the way they define and limit their use of this loaded word. In this course we examine both the idea and the manifestation of these wildernesses, questioning the assumptions and the rhetoric we use when talking about the existence, construction, representation, cultivation, or manipulation of nature in our urban environment. We immerse ourselves in classics of American nature writing and then venture into the city, using our texts as lenses for reading such spaces as Central Park, the High Line, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and the American Natural History Museum. Readings include selections by Henry David Thoreau, John Burroughs, Aldo Leopold, Rachel Carson, Loren Eiseley, Annie Dillard, Terry Tempest Williams, bell hooks, Wendell Berry, and William Cronon, among others. Students compose both critical analyses of the texts and their own nature writing based on their exploration of and research into their own “patch” of New York wilderness. TARA K. PARMITER is a Senior Language Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program and a Mentor in the Undergraduate Writing Tutors Program. Her research interests include literature and the environment, turn-of-the-twentieth century women’s literature, children’s literature, travel narratives, and popular culture. She has published on topics ranging from the imagined landscapes in L. M. Montgomery’s Anne of Green Gables novels to summer vacationing in Kate Chopin’s The Awakening to journey narratives in the Muppet movies. She received her B.A. from Cornell and her Ph.D. in English and American Literature from NYU.  Spring 2014 Reading Toni Morrison FRSEM-UA 523; class # 14612 Instructor: Elizabeth McHenry Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.–noon Required cohort meeting: Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Winner of the 1993 Nobel Prize for Literature, Toni Morrison was the eighth woman and first African American ever to receive that award. In its citation, the Swedish Academy praised her as someone “who, in novels characterized by visionary force and poetic import, gives life to an essential aspect of American reality.” This course seeks to identify and to examine that “essential aspect of American reality.” We read the writings of Morrison, exploring the ways in which she represents history, identity, nation, race, gender, sexuality, and community in novels and essays that both challenge and complicate our understanding of these themes. Our aim is to understand the formal aspects of her writing—how her novels “work” as literature—as well as the cultural and historical interventions it makes. We also take up questions about Morrison’s reputation among contemporary readers of her fiction, and the various outlets, including Oprah’s Book Club, where it has been championed. Students taking this class should expect to read great books that inspire hard conversations about race, gender, sexuality, and American social and cultural history; through our reading, several short papers, and a research project of their own design students hone their skills as critical readers, original researchers, and persuasive writers. ELIZABETH MCHENRY, Associate Professor of English, is the author of Forgotten Readers: Recovering the Lost History of African American Literary Societies , which received the John Hope Franklin Book Award, the Society for the History of Authorship, Reading, and Publishing Book History Award, and the American Library Association Award for Non-Fiction. She is the recipient of fellowships from the Ford Foundation and the National Humanities Center, and is currently a co-editor of the New York University Press series, America and the Long Nineteenth Century . Her research interests and teaching are primarily focused on American and African American literary history, print culture studies, and archival research methods.  Spring 2014 Atlantic Migrations since 1600 FRSEM-UA 524; class # 14629 Instructor: Joe Lee  syllabus Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) The movement of people, voluntarily and involuntarily, from Europe and Africa across the Atlantic to North and South America since about 1600 is one of the epochal events in world history. It has had a major impact—and in many cases has left an indelible mark—on the histories of both the sending and receiving of societies and cultures, whether the multitudes involved moved as free men and women, as indentured servants, or as slaves. This course seeks to understand the causes and consequences, economic, social, political and cultural, of these massive movements of human beings. JOE LEE has been Professor of History and Irish Studies at NYU since 2002, and is Glucksman Chair of Irish Studies and Director of Glucksman Ireland House NYU. He was previously at University College Cork (Ireland), where he chaired the History Department and served for periods as Dean of Arts and as Vice President. He is a former Member of the Upper House of the Irish Parliament and former Member of the British-Irish Parliamentary Body; he also served as the Chair of the Fulbright Commission for Ireland and as President of the Irish Association for European Studies. He is author of two seminal histories of Ireland, The Modernization of Irish Society, 1848–1918 and the prize-winning Ireland, 1912–1985: Politics and Society . His op-ed columns for the Sunday Tribune were collected as The Shifting Balance of Power: Exploring the 20th Century , and he recently co-edited Making the Irish American: The History and Heritage of the Irish in the United States with Marion R. Casey. Nueva York, New York FRSEM-UA 525; class # 18469 Instructor: James D. Fernández Wednesday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with Experimental Physics I (Monday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) Prerequisite: reading knowledge of Spanish and/or a score of 4 or 5 on any AP Spanish exam (or international equivalent). According to demographers, in the near future one out of every three New Yorkers will be of Hispanic origin. Far from being a recent phenomenon, the presence of Spanish-speaking people in the city can be traced back almost to the origins of the city in the seventeenth century. In the first part of this course we study the history of links between New York City and the Spanish-speaking world, from the arrival of 23 Sephardic Jews to the town of New Amsterdam in 1654, to the arrival of Spanish refugees fleeing from Fascism in the early 1940s. During the second part of the course, participants contribute to the creation of a website that will map and document traces of Spain and Spanish-speakers in the city of New York. We make a number of field trips during the semester, and one of the assignments is to design and script a walking tour. Readings include texts by José Martí (Cuba), Bernardo Vega (Puerto Rico) and Federico García Lorca (Spain). JAMES D. FERNÁNDEZ is Associate Professor in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. His research interests include the literature, history, and culture of modern Spain; autobiography; cultural relations between Spain and Latin America; and visions of Spain in the United States. He served as the inaugural director of NYU’s King Juan Carlos I of Spain Center from 1995 to 2007, and as Chair of his department from 2003 to 2007. He is the Vice Chair of the Board of Governors of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives, and co-editor of the collection of essays Facing Fascism: New York and the Spanish Civil War . He is the author of Apology to Apostrophe: Autobiography and the Rhetoric of Self-Representation in Spain.  Spring 2014 Biography's Many Lives FRSEM-UA 526; class # 14605 Instructor: Victoria Olsen  syllabus  Thursday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) The genre of biography has traced lives of "famous men" since Plutarch and Boswell's Johnson, but its conventional forms and techniques have come into question over the last century. This course examines how biography provides a window into different periods, cultures, and disciplines and how it has had to stretch to incorporate new voices, methodologies, and techniques. From Virginia Woolf's Orlando to Rebecca Skloot's Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, biography has pushed the boundaries of literary form and scientific knowledge. We read a broad range of subjects and styles—exploring issues of research, writing, and reading—to become biographers of the genre itself. VICTORIA OLSEN, Ph.D. is a Senior Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program, where she teaches Writing the Essay to freshmen at Tisch and Writing and Speaking in the Disciplines to undergraduates in CAS. She has been a writing consultant and mentor to writing tutors in psychology, biology, philosophy, and history courses. She is the author of the biography From Life: Julia Margaret Cameron and Victorian Photography.  Spring 2014 Cultures of Science and Belief FRSEM-UA 527; class # 14992 Instructor: Noelle J. Molé  syllabus   Monday and Wednesday, 2:00-3:15 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 11:00 a.m.–noon We regularly take for granted that scientific knowledge is objective, a universal truth unchanged by history and culture. The laws of physics are just as true in Indonesia as they are in Mexico or the United States. Yet we also know that scientific knowledge is constantly in flux. What we “knew” to be true yesterday (e.g., the world is flat) is not true today, and new discoveries revolutionize what we knew (e.g., germ theory, epigenetics). This seminar positions science along a spectrum of worldviews—explanatory models that provide causal reasons and underlying logics for events and actions—a spectrum that includes magic, occultism, witchcraft, science, spirituality, and religion. A single hurricane might be explained, within particular historical and cultural contexts, as being sent by a witch’s curse, a moving cold front, or an angry god. How we position ourselves between these ways of knowing is not, of course, mutually exclusive and the threshold between the categories is actually more blurred than we might initially expect. Interrogating the similarities and differences between “knowledge” and “belief,” this course questions our deeply held assumptions regarding the neutrality of science and the so-called backwardness of folk belief. How do socio-cultural contexts and economic systems shape the production of scientific knowledge? Why do certain theories achieve recognition as rational and correct? We explore the social, economic, and political implications of these hierarchies of knowledge, and examine how they shape how we experience our own bodies, our own feelings, and even our own minds. NOELLE J. MOLÉ is a cultural anthropologist and author of Labor Disorders in Neoliberal Italy: Mobbing, Well-being and the Workplace . She is currently investigating the rise of scientific skepticism and supernatural beliefs in Italy as twin responses to a millennial crisis in knowledge production. She is a Senior Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program.  Spring 2014 The Art of Note Taking FRSEM-UA 528; class # 14606 Instructor: Louis Bury Wednesday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 3:30–4:30 p.m. Taking notes is first and foremost a utilitarian act, a way of recording information for the purposes of future use and improved retention. But notes also possess, importantly, an aesthetic dimension: splayed across the page in poetic fragments, they present a veritable graph of a mind in motion. In this course we consider note taking as both an aesthetic and utilitarian act. Our course readings focus on exemplary notes, diaries, and journals by prominent 20th century writers and artists, as well as older species of textual response such as Talmudic commentary and marginalia on Medieval manuscripts. We may also consider contemporary forms of digital writing that verge on note taking, such as blog posts, tweets, and Internet commentary. We use these texts as both source material and inspiration for our own extensive note taking. The goal is not simply to help you to become a better note taker but to help you understand how note taking is itself a form of writing and of thinking and not merely preparation for the "real" writing that you submit to your professors. Course requirements include: weekly reading and note taking; a midterm presentation; one short essay; and a final research project, developed out of your weekly notes. LOUIS BURY is a Language Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program. His first book, Exercises in Criticism: The Theory and Practice of Literary Constraint (Dalkey Archive Press, forthcoming) applies rules and restrictions in order to write poetic, autobiographical literary criticism. He is currently taking notes for a book on literary note taking.  Spring 2014 Sensual Shifts: From Looking to Listening in Modernist Literature FRSEM-UA 529; class # 14607 Instructor: Angela Frattarola  syllabus Monday and Wednesday, 3:30-4:45 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.-noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.). From Greek philosophy to the Enlightenment, vision was the privileged sense. Traditionally associated with knowledge and rationality, vision encourages a subject to keep a distanced, analytical perspective of an object. But does this always have to be the case? Can the other senses allow new ways of conceiving of and experiencing the relationship between the self and the world? This seminar begins by examining the dominance of vision in modernity and turns to audition as a way of thinking about alternative perceptions of the self and the world. We accomplish this by closely reading modernist novels that suggest a growing skepticism toward vision and heightened attention to sound and listening. In order to think about why modernists brought sound to the forefront of their art, we attempt to gain a sense of the modernist soundscape and the new auditory technologies of the time. Readings for the course consist of essays from sound studies as well as novels by Virginia Woolf, Dorothy Richardson, Jean Rhys, and James Joyce. ANGELA FRATTAROLA is a Senior Lecturer and Writing Tutor Mentor in NYU's Expository Writing Program. Her essays on modernist literature have appeared in such journals as Modern Drama, Genre, Mosaic, Studies in the Novel, Journal of Modern Literature, and Woolf Studies Annual . She has nearly completed a manuscript entitled Auditory Narrative in the Modernist Novel: Early Twentieth-Century Soundscapes and Audio-Technologies , a study that examines how modernist literature was shaped by developing auditory technologies and changes in auditory perception at the turn of the century.  Spring 2014 Rediscovering Bacchic Revelry FRSEM-UA 530; class # 15031 Instructor: Megan Shea  syllabus Wednesday, 11:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.-noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.). When we think about the staging of ancient Greek theater, we often envision a static stage where a masked man recites a lengthy monologue in an outdoor theater. But such a vision hardly describes the dynamic celebration of music, sexuality, and poetry that infused the City Dionysia and the Lenaia—the Athenian festivals centered on tragedy and comedy in the sixth through the fourth Centuries B.C.E. In this seminar, we reimagine the performance of Greek theater by witnessing current productions of Greek plays, engaging with New York City’s various collections of Greek art objects, studying contemporary festivals and celebrations, poring through critical interpretations of Greek history, and returning to textual evidence (the plays!). Beyond reconstructing our own understandings of ancient performance, we use the discord between our original scenarios of Greek performance and our revisions to evaluate how we conceive of Western civilization’s past. Weekly response papers, a performance/design project, and a final research paper help awaken our sense of ancient performative acts. MEGAN SHEA is a language lecturer in NYU’s Expository Writing Program. She received her Ph.D. in Theater Arts from Cornell University, where she studied women’s performance in ancient Greece and the contemporary West. While teaching at Cornell, she received the Gertrude Spencer Student Portfolio Award, and she has received several Excellence in Teaching awards while at NYU. Dr. Shea has published articles in The Journal for Dramatic Theory and Criticism and TheatreForum . She recently premiered her translation of Euripides’ Cyclops at Dixon Place.  Spring 2014 Left Brain, Right Brain, Whole Brain: Acts of Knowledge, Discovery, and Creation FRSEM-UA 531; class # 14608 Instructor: David Ellis  syllabus  Tuesday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Artists and scientists are often split into separate camps in the university and in our collective imagination; this split can even divide our individual minds. “Left brains”—the analytical, logical, objective among us—become engineers, biologists, and bankers while “right brains”—intuitive, thoughtful, subjective—are the painters, philosophers, and social workers of the world. In practice, in the science lab or in the artist’s studio, these distinctions may be more porous than we popularly believe. This seminar explores the interplay between reasoning, knowledge, belief, discovery, and creativity—acts of mind common to all fields in the academy. Whether presented to us in the “real world,” the arts, or philosophy, we will wrestle with conundrums which resist easy solution. We explore many branches—logic, physics, neurology, psychology, literature, film, visual and performance art—hunting for approaches to understanding which we then put into practice. We work towards the goal of “understanding our understanding,” as the artist Matthew Goulish phrases it, in order to exploit the twinned powers of rationality and creativity. Trips to MoMath (Museum of Mathematics), MoMA, and other outings are planned. In his “right-brained” work as a poet, fiction writer, and visual artist, DAVID ELLIS explores science topics with a humanities approach, such as the nature of time, memory, sensory perception, social dynamics, and spatial relationships. His work in NYU’s Writing in the Disciplines program has taken him into a range of “left-brained” classrooms, from astrophysics to psychology, and at the City University of New York he teamed up with a geologist and a classicist who specializes in Roman artifacts to teach a series a classes with shared research and creative practices, which was the basis of their work “Volcanoes, Vases, and Creation Stories.” He teaches in the Expository Writing Program at NYU. Natural and Artificial Intelligence FRSEM-UA 532; class # 18663 Instructor: Gary Marcus  syllabus Wednesday, 12:30–3:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 2:00–3:00 p.m. Prerequisite: Programming experience recommended. Who's smarter—Siri or Einstein? Is a "singularity" imminent? Through readings in psychology, philosophy, neuroscience, and computer science, we compare brains and computers, their relative strengths and weaknesses, and the prospects for human-level artificial intelligence. Topics include language, vision, game-playing, robotics, common-sense reasoning, and computational creativity. GARY MARCUS, Professor of Psychology and Director of the NYU Center for Child Language, is a cognitive scientist interested in the origins and nature of human mental life. His books include The Birth of the Mind: How a Tiny Number of Genes Creates the Complexity of Human Thought; The Norton Psychology Reader; and Kluge: The Haphazard Evolution of the Human Mind .  New Worlds, Old Worlds: Travelers and Pilgrims in Renaissance Europe and the Americas FRSEM-UA 533; class # 19001 Instructor: Jane Tylus Monday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with Introductory Experimental Physics I (Monday 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) Renaissance men—and women—found themselves at the intersection of colliding ideas about the worlds they lived in. They both looked back to antiquity and the Bible, and ahead to new and unpredictable changes regarding religion, geography, and science. The literature of travel in the period bears witness to the instability and excitement of the centuries that bear the hallmarks of the “early modern.” Travelers included pilgrims and knights going off on crusade and missionaries going off to convert, as well as explorers, merchants, and inevitably, exiles. If pilgrimage was about the return to a “center”—Jerusalem most prominently, but also Rome— exploration meant voyaging to an unknown periphery, and exilic wandering meant heading toward a new and uncertain home. We explore the period from roughly 1300 to 1700 through travel literature ranging from pilgrimage accounts to Columbus’s letters to an epic about the first Crusade. We also look at such alternate accounts as the Aztec version of the conquista and Arabic responses to the Crusades. The course includes visiting at least one museum in New York and studying cartographic images at the New York Public Library. Students produce collaborative in-class presentations as well as a final paper exploring their own personal journey through the new and old worlds they encountered during their first semester of college. JANE TYLUS is Professor of Italian Studies and Comparative Literature at NYU, as well as faculty director of the Humanities Initiative. Prior to coming to NYU in 2003 she taught at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. While her research focus of late has been on Italian women writers—she is the award-winning author of Reclaiming Catherine of Siena: Literature, Literacy, and the Signs of Others and translator of the poetry of Gaspara Stampa and Lucrezia Tornabuoni—she is really a comparatist at heart, and her favorite courses are on the "great books" of world literature. Her current projects are books on the beautiful Tuscan hill-town of Siena and on medieval and early modern pilgrimage. On Being Human FRSEM-UA 534; class # 19002 Instructors: G. Gabrielle Starr & Jane Tylus Thursday, 9:30 a.m.–noon Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with Principles of Biology I (Monday and Wednesday 9:30–10:45 a.m.) and with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) The sciences are united by their method of inquiry into the natural world and the social sciences in their study of human behavior, but the humanities seem different —rich, heterogeneous, or perhaps even fragmented. Different or not, the humanities offer unique and powerful models that help us think about and understand the world we inhabit. We study ideas that have been foci of humanist inquiry from the ancient world to the present, and engage these ideas to show what humanist thought has to contribute to some big questions about human life. These ideas include simile (with a focus on pain, trauma, and the medical humanities), evidence (digital humanities, archives, and jurisprudence), dialogue (music, drama), empathy (history and philosophy), and ekphrasis (art history and literature). The course features site visits to the places where humanist engagement matters (hospitals, archives, museums, and even law courts) and encourages students to reflect upon their possible career paths as well as the connections among different disciplines, eras, and methodologies. Finally, the course considers why New York City and NYU are crucial for the humanities in the twenty-first century, in light of the City’s diverse nature and NYU’s identity as a global university. G. GABRIELLE STARR is Professor of English and Seryl Kushner Dean of the College of Arts and Science. She has published widely on eighteenth-century British literature and the history of the aesthetic. With collaborators in NYU’s Center for Neural Science she has pursued research in the field of neuroaesthetics and published the results in Frontiers in Human Neuroscience . In addition, Dean Starr has just completed a book entitled Feeling Beauty: Aesthetic Experience in the Brain and Across the Arts. JANE TYLUS is Professor of Italian Studies and Comparative Literature at NYU, as well as faculty director of the Humanities Initiative. Prior to coming to NYU in 2003 she taught at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. While her research focus of late has been on Italian women writers—she is the award-winning author of Reclaiming Catherine of Siena: Literature, Literacy and the Signs of Others and translator of the poetry of Gaspara Stampa and Lucrezia Tornabuoni—she is really a comparatist at heart, and her favorite courses are on the "great books" of world literature. Her current projects are books on the beautiful Tuscan hill-town of Siena and on medieval and early modern pilgrimage.  Spring 2014 Cataclysm and Voice in the Twentieth-Century Novel FRSEM-UA 535; class # 15225 Instructor: Leeore Schnairsohn Tuesday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.-noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.). The course examines how novelists of the twentieth century responded to the cataclysms, both conceptual and historical, of that slippery and multifarious period of time. At the century's opening, people were trying to get a grip on things like airplanes and telephones and relativity theory and the Russian Revolution. Concurrently, artists were changing the way they made art, and kept changing it as the century continued to provoke them. We read some astounding novelists and consider their voices in conversation with the cataclysms of their times. We also write in response to the ways our world is changing at the turn of this new century, and attempt experiments with fiction and essay to construct true slivers of experience that speak from our own historical position. The class period is divided between discussion of the week's reading and a creative writing workshop. In addition to a final critical essay, students are expected to contribute one piece of creative prose (likely some form of fiction) to the workshop, and complete weekly writing assignments (some creative, some in response to the reading, some both). LEEORE SCHNAIRSOHN holds a Ph.D. in Comparative Literature from Princeton and is currently a Language Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program at NYU. His translations of the Russian poet Osip Mandelstam have appeared in Portals and Inventory ; he has also published review articles in the Slavic and East European Journal and Canadian-American Slavic Studies . He is at work on a vampire novel and a non-vampire novel.  Spring 2014 Race and Culture in Brazil FRSEM-UA 536; class # 15924 Instructor: Dylon Robbins Monday, 2:00-4:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 10:00–11:00 a.m. Note: conflicts with Principles of Biology I (Monday and Wednesday 9:30–10:45 a.m.) Brazil is often invoked in conversations about race and culture. Whether as an example of presumably more egalitarian race relations, or as a regional culture embodying an exceptional fusion of African, Indigenous, and European elements, Brazil is a model for understanding heterogeneity and difference. And yet it is also a nation frequently cited for its incidence of violence and extreme economic inequality. We explore some of the unique contradictions shaping Brazilian reality as related to notions of race and culture by tracing the history of race relations in the ongoing transformation of Brazilian culture, examining such key examples and events as slavery and the plantation economy, popular music, Carnival, populism, racial democracy, affirmative action, and urban and rural violence. How do race and culture coincide and diverge in Brazil? And what may we gather about these convergences and divergences from textual, musical, and cinematic examples? DYLON ROBBINS is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. He teaches courses on Brazil and the Caribbean, with particular interest in the cultural and theoretical production of these regions, in addition to that of the African Diasporas in general, with particular concern for intellectual and cultural histories, media, cinema, and popular music. His work is supported by archival research in Brazil as a Fulbright-Hays fellow at the Cinemateca Brasileira and the Instituto de Estudos Brasileiros, and in Cuba at the ICAIC, the Biblioteca Nacional, and Casa de las Américas. He is currently completing his book manuscript on popular music and political subjectivity in Brazil.  Spring 2014 Lincoln in Time: Private and Public Transformations   FRSEM-UA 537; class # 16575 Instructor: Philip Kunhardt    syllabus Thursday, 11:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 2:00-3:00 p.m.   This seminar engages students in an exploration of Abraham Lincoln's  transformative leadership, a touchstone for all subsequent American  presidencies. We closely explore the personal Lincoln, always in the  context of his times and their challenges, and see how a series of  wrenching personal crises sorely tested but also helped forge Lincoln's  character. Through the study of key texts, through intensive group  discussion, and through written and spoken communication, the seminar  presents students with a series of questions: Is there a moral realm with  which human actors engage for good or ill? How do private decisions and  inner resolves impact unfolding events? And how do figures like Lincoln  manage to grow past limitations of viewpoint and errors of judgment to  embrace universal human values and commitments?  We examine Lincoln's role in the Civil War, his use of political rhetoric,  and his impact upon American civil liberties. How did the issues of  slavery and race intersect with his development as a public figure? How  was he influenced by other figures around him-southerners, abolitionists,  former slaves, politicians? And how did he learn to use words so  effectively to help produce social transformation? Concurrent with a close  study of Lincoln's written and spoken words, and of the political, social,  and interpersonal context of his times, students also wrestle with the  vital question of how they can construct their own lives.     PHILIP KUNHARDT is Distinguished Scholar in Residence in the Humanities,  and teaches history and biography in the College of Arts and Science. He  focuses on the lives of transformative figures and has co-authored five  books, including Looking for Lincoln, The American President, and P.T.  Barnum: America's Greatest Showman. He was also writer and co-producer of  more than a dozen documentary films for PBS, ABC, HBO, Discovery, and  others, including the ten-part PBS series The American President, and the  sixteen part Freedom: A History of US.  Before coming to NYU he was a Bard Center Fellow at Bard College in  Annandale, New York.  Spring 2014 Pirates, Privateers and Other Maritime Renegades of the Caribbean FRSEM-UA 538; class # 16278 Instructor: Edgardo Morales  syllabus Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m. Pirates, privateers and runaways of the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth century Caribbean fought, stole, lied and killed in order to make a living and either to collaborate with or oppose bosses and empires. Today, the Jolly Roger --the pirate flag-- is clearly displayed in toys and makes for compelling cinematic moments. In real life, however, flying that flag was a criminal act punishable with the death penalty. How must we think of Francis Drake, the most feared privateer of the 1500s, in the age of Jack Sparrow, the most renown of the fantasy pirates of our days? This class will approach the history of maritime renegades as an opportunity to develop historical research and writing skills, and to help us think critically about topics that might otherwise escape scholarly inquiry. While outsiders often described pirates and privateers as renegades, godless,   murderers and villains, privateer men like Francis Drake,   pirate women like Anne Bonny, or runaway slaves like Tom King lived at   the very center of important political questions of their age. Students will read academic books such as Villains of All Nations , by the historian Marcus Rediker, as well as original documents dating back to the age of piracy. Prof. EDGARDO PEREZ MORALES graduated with a Ph.D in history from the University of Michigan. He has conducted research on privateers during the Age of Revolutions in archives and libraries in Colombia, Cuba, France, Jamaica, Spain and the United States. He teaches at NYU’s Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies.                        Welcome!
